verse.roman:
dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca
yathā vadati kalyāṇīṁ
vācaṁ dāna-pate bhavān
tathānayā na tṛpyāmi
martyaḥ prāpya yathāmṛtam

synonyms: dhṛtarāṣṭraḥ uvāca—Dhṛtarāṣṭra said; yathā—as; vadati—speak; kalyāṇīm—auspicious; vācam—words; dāna—of charity; pate—O master; bhavān—you; tathā—so; anayā—by this; na tṛpyāmi—I am not satiated; martyaḥ—a mortal; prāpya—attaining; yathā—as if; amṛtam—the nectar of immortality.
translation: Dhṛtarāṣṭra said: O master of charity, I can never be satiated while hearing your auspicious words. Indeed, I am like a mortal who has obtained the nectar of the gods.

purport.text: In the opinion of Śrīla Viśvanātha Cakravartī, Dhṛtarāṣṭra was in fact proud and felt he already knew everything Akrūra was speaking, but to maintain diplomatic gravity he spoke as a saintly gentleman.
